channel.title: KenSmith tweets
channel.description: A feed of recent tweets from KenSmith.

item.description: Thucydides depicts Pericles describing the far-reaching civic values of Athens. https://t.co/2MaYvpOhcS https://t.co/O82skokXL0 https://t.co/o997LcK3Ja https://t.co/oXtLx0eDCD

‘Art should provide people with emotions they have never experienced before, ones they’ve never felt. It’s not about making people cry, but rather that the tear should fall in a certain way, when one least expects it, and for reasons he doesn’t understand.’ —Raúl Ruiz
‘Be careful about reading health books. You may die of a misprint.’ Attributed to Mark Twain.

@davewiner A jazz musician says, Let's see where we two can take this tune by heading north-northeast. In time, the second musician replies, Very interesting locale we've come to, now let's try a little further south.
Outwintering cattle in the northwest of England. Comments by @HerdyShepherd1 James Rebanks and others. https://t.co/tCvP8sPVJu
Consider the endless circus of white people and white men she has been facing. https://t.co/RwVLXF6OFV
No, says Instagram, we’re going to be a video site now. Sorry, small business owners . . . https://t.co/eZRCz4plEm
What does media concentration do to a country? Today, Tuesday, 7:30 pm London time, a live stream discussion of a good question. https://t.co/nhnh3wzGqx https://t.co/jyf6eFOjOf
Home, Sweet Home. https://t.co/h2E9KvCbMq

“That coffee has a great aroma, it’s all through my truck. I’m going to order some,” the letter carrier said, pointing to the shipping bag now in my hand. He didn’t know that @HelioRoast had roasted the beans to our specs just a couple of days before. https://t.co/Uc5HRuZkHg
“That’s how they taught us…” From “Not To Read” by Alejandro Zambra. https://t.co/sv3Ro9beh3
A fun question to ask bookstore customers and employees for short videos. https://t.co/zd5ad50NWT
Heading to the art show on Saturday. https://t.co/Ulbqlsh2iz
Protest, Broadway outside the 96th Street subway station. https://t.co/M7VxxyOKJu
Metro Diner, Broadway—“Harsh & Delicious” or something like that. https://t.co/oEtHGjvfrY
It made an excellent poster back in college, but look, there’s the thing itself right there on that wall. (Kandinsky, huge show at the Googs.) https://t.co/3kCxDDf2xP

Central Park, first warm and sunny Friday, dozens of nearby humans stretching their legs, mostly ignoring the raccoon in its ample winter coat scratching at a puddle on the lawn. Two teen lads with fallen branches ponder how close they dare come to the raccoon before throwing.

Fun in Manhattan—walk the High Line park on the old elevated train tracks between 13th and 30th, say, look over at the very nearby apartments of some affluent folks, see and enjoy the art they’ve got on their walls, and, if you like, judge it. Plus street murals. https://t.co/cwsjxrRxGj

“We must emerge from this convention with an independent, Black political agenda, a dynamic program for Black liberation that in the process will liberate America from its current decadence.” https://t.co/MgdVviVSI4
I needed 600 words by noon on Thursday, but I had to write 2000 words to find them.
“He knows these citizens have the power to do strong things again.” https://t.co/n0TugBB7H4
Overheard on the sidewalk just now. “I think it depends your therapist, though.”
My new radio piece is about the joys of just making up statistics. https://t.co/X0lXiz4trh

“The night before his [family] was relocated to an internment camp…Gyo boarded a train to St. Louis to continue his architectural training at Washington University, … one of the only U.S. universities that would accept Japanese-American students.” https://t.co/EzhDHG8Rpa

The National Review on “Trump’s baggage, his torpidness, his ill-discipline, his self-indulgence, his abject disregard for our constitutional order, his pathological, unyielding, surrealistic dishonesty.” https://t.co/R1lupY2O7L
